During his stay at Athens, Horace made the acquaintance of many young Romans of noble birth2, by whom apparently he was introduced, in September B.c. 44, to M. Junius BrutusÂ³, the Liberator. Brutus, at this time, was passing through Athens on his way to the province of Macedonia which had been assigned to him (as propraetor) by Julius Caesar before his murder. (Cassius meanwhile was proceeding to his province, Syria.) As governor of Macedonia, Brutus was collecting an army, partly to oppose C. Antonius, who claimed the province as nominee of the senate, and partly to combat some turbulent tribes of Thracians, who were harassing the borders. In this army, Horace received the appointment of military tribune4. He marched with the troops through Macedonia and Thrace, crossed the Hellespont, saw a good deal of Asia Minorâµ and returned with the combined forces of Brutus and Cassius to the field of Philippi (Nov. B.C. 42). In the first battle at this place, Brutus was victoriousÍ¾ in the second (twenty days later) he was defeated, and Horace fledss, never to bear arms again.
